text:
Absolutely delicous!!! My husband loved it!!!! I did as some others suggested and bought the pre-sliced beef stir fry strips to make it a little quicker. The ony other thing I did was sliced my green peppers into strips instead of chopping them. I would definitely recommend adding the peppers when the dish is almost done though because they get really mushy and if you like crisper peppers I would add them last.

text:
Don't be fooled by the name.  This is not a traditionally prepared Chinese Pepper Steak but it is very good nonetheless.  In addition to seasoning the beef with garlic powder, I added red pepper flakes and fresh minced garlic to the crock pot.  Also, I suggest adding the green pepper during the last couple of hours of cooking so that they maintain a crispy texture (I added mine at the beginning and they were very mushy).  Finally, I added a tablespoon or so of cornstarch (mixed with cool water) just before serving.  This created a wonderful gravy that was perfect over rice.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This recipe was DELICIOUS and sooooo easy to make! My grocery store had pre-sliced "Beef For Stir-Fry" on sale, so I substituted that for the sirloin and it turned out fantastic (it also saved alot of time and effort not having to slice the meat myself)! I followed the recipe exactly and it was done after about 6 hours on low... the meat was super tender and almost falling apart! The sauce was a little bit thinner than I like, so I took another tablespoon of cornstarch and mixed it in a small bowl with a little bit of the sauce, then dumped it back into the crockpot and mixed it up real well. Then I let it cook on low for another 30 minutes and this thickened the sauce up perfectly! I served it over steamed white rice and then served the leftovers the next day with mashed potatoes -- both were YUMMY! My husband and I really loved this recipe and I'll definitely be making it again!

text:
This is part of my regular fall/winter rotation.  I find it is best to put the peppers in during the last hour of cooking, so they aren't dissintegrated.  Also, I find that I need additional cornstarch at the end (when I add the peppers) to make the sauce thicker.

text:
One of the best recipes from this site that we have tried. Hubby, kids and granddaughter absolutely love it! I followed the recipe pretty close, only making a few minor changes to use what was on hand. I used probably closer to 2 1/2 pounds of sirloin completely trimmed of any fat, a whole large vidalia onion, 4 bell peppers (1 each green, red, orange and yellow) and low sodium soy sauce. I also did not add the peppers in the beginning with the the other ingredients. I waited until approx. 2 hours before serving. They were very tender but not mushy. Served over Jasime rice. The meat is so tender it just melts in your mouth and the flavor is excellent. Simple, hearty, comfort food. This will be added to our "favorites file". Thanks for sharing!

text:
I was nervous about this but it was a big hit...Nothing left in the crock pot when dinner was over...I fed 4 men and they kept dipping the serving spoon back in the pot!!!  I took the following suggestions from others:  2 cans beef broth instead of bouillon, 1 green and 1 red pepper, 1 clove fresh garlic, double the soy sauce (I used light), leave out the salt, add worcestire and plenty of it, add the peppers in the last hour.  Add more cornstarch or flour while cooking for thickness.  And I think 3 to 4 hours on low is plenty.  I'm sure I'll be asked to make this again :)

Such an easy, versatile recipe which can be customized to each family's personal likes and dislikes.  I often add pineapple, bamboo shoots, mushrooms, carrots, or whatever I have in the fridge that might complement it.  My only recommendation would be to use fresh minced garlic instead of the powdered garlic and low sodium soy sauce vs the regular soy sauce to reduce the saltiness of the dish. Thanks MJWagner68 for the submission.

text:
I wish I had read other reviews first.  After cooking 7 hours on low, mine did turn to mush, but I loved the flavor so much that I will attempt this one again.  It wasn't necessary to brown the meat first.  I did make it again, and loved the changes I made:  used 1 cup water, 1 bouillon, and 2 Tbl. cornstarch.  Cooked the meat and spices (no onions and peppers yet) for 3 1/2 hours.  Added the onions and peppers, then cooked for another 1 1/2 hour to 2 hours.  Thanks for the recipe!!

text:
I believe the nutrition data for this recipe was calculated on the basis that lean sirloin beef is used. Out of curiosity I recalculated it for a fatty sirloin, and it comes out high calorie, high trans fats, and high cholesterol. It's important to be aware that for a healthy meal, lean beef is needed.  Give a miss to the fattier cuts and avoid having it deposited around your waistline :-)

text:
This recipe is fantastic--it is now an established favorite at our house.  I use whatever beef is cheapest.  I have also made this a convenience food by browning the seasoned beef and freezing it along with the onion and pepper strips.  The morning I want to make it I dump the frozen ziplock of goodies in with the rest of the ingredients and turn the crockpot on!  I also never add the salt and use reduced sodium soy sauce and we don't miss it at all.

text:
I have been making this recipe now for a couple of years & it is one of my favorites.  Changed very little.  Browned top round steak in olive oil, doubled all the sauce ingredients, added 2 packages of Hungry Jack Brown Gravy mix, and only added about 1/4 of the peppers at the beginning for flavor(otherwise they get too mushy).  Added the rest 1 1/2 hours before the end.  Cooked on low for 6 hours and comes out perfect and delicious every time.  Best served over egg noodles tossed with olive oil , onion powder and parsley flakes.

I also cut out the extra tspn of salt...really not needed.  Aside from that I cut out the garlic powder and used 3 cloves fresh garlic and a 1/2 tspn of ground ginger.  This is a keeper...thanks for the recipe.

Display Name:
CHAMMI

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674161.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This was delicious. I couldn't keep from sampling the sauce.

Although browning the meat and making the broth is a hassle, I would still be willing to make this again.

I used very lean pre-tenderized stew meat, which is about a dollar more at the supermarket than non-tenderized stew meat, but less expensive than sirloin tips.

This meat could have been more tender, but was not bad at all-- similar to the pepper steak in most Chinese restaurants. 

I added liberal amounts of garlic powder, black pepper, and cayenne pepper (as I like spicy dishes).

I also added some diced white onion that I had on hand, as well as cooking sherry and green onion, cut into 1-2 inch pieces.

I agree with the cook who suggested doubling the sauce ingredients. The sauce didn't seem thick enough with the cornstarch, although this is a problem I usually have. I ended up using 3 Tbsp., which works out to 1+1/2 Tbsp. if you do not double the sauce. At that point it worked out well. Finally, I used powdered Au Jus mix rather than bouillion cubes.

Next time, I would cut the stewed tomatoes so that the pieces wouldn't be so large.

As a note to those on a low-sodium diet: this dish  is quite salty (although fine for my tastes). Perhaps one could use low sodium soy sauce and beef bouillion and half the amount of salt added?

text:
This is something I will cook up again for busy school nights. As per some reviews, the only changes I made were to add the peppers on the fourth hour out of six in the crock pot (on low) and they were perfect, and 30 minutes before done, I  turned the crock pot to high and added 1 tbsp of corn starch well mixed into 1/2 cup of hot water which gave me a thicker sauce - served on white rice. I mentionned at the table that next time, I would add some pineapple and everyone agreed that it would really be good, so I'll try it next time, but overall, it took 5 minutes to prepare and was very good... for me, it's a keeper!

text:
I LOVED this recipe.  For my dish, I replaced the powdered garlic with 4 cloves of fresh garlic. I minced my garlic and sauted with 2 tbls of Butter. I browned the meat in the garlic/butter sauce. I used 1 tbls of Soy, and 3 tbls of Worchester. I didn't add any salt.  I used a 1 green, 1 red and 1 orange bell pepper added 1 hour before finished. Next time I will use 4 peppers.  I also added 1tsp of crushed red pepper for some kick.  I wound up using 3 tbls of cornstarch and substituted the bullion cube and water for one 10oz can of beef broth.

This dish was delicious, it will definitely go in my rotation.  I served with Basmati Rice and sweet cornbread.

text:
This is soo much better the next day when it's had time to set.  I added the green peppers halfway also cause of the other reviews.   I added some tabasco at the end cuase it needed a kick.  Also since the sauce was so soupy when it was done I added more cornstarch.  That night I wasn't sure if I like the reciepe.  The next day while I was preparing the leftovers I loved how the gravy had thickend and it was soo good over rice.  My recommendation is to make this the night before then put it in the refrigerator and eat it the next day.

text:
Very tasty.  I will make again.  It was a little time consuming to brown the meat before putting in the crockpot but once in, it made dinner prep easy that evening.  I did as others suggested and doubled the sauce ingredients for additional gravy.  I tried it over brown rice and Angel Hair Pasta (all I had).  We preferred the pasta so next time I'll get egg noodles.  I used 3 cups beef broth (double recipe) with 2T cornstarch rather than the bouillon as suggested and doubled all gravy ingredients + added 1/2 t. of cayene pepper.  At the end I thickened it again with 2T cornstarch in cool water as others suggested.  Hubby & daughter liked it.

country:
None
text:
Much too heavy on the salt. I think the soy sauce is the culprit. That stuff is a sodium bomb and it can take over any recipe where it's an ingredient. 

I've made almost this same recipe for years on the stove top. The only difference between the two recipes is that the one I use (copied from a 1960s magazine at the library) calls for 2 teaspoons of Worcestershire rather than 3 tablespoons of soy sauce. 

I tried making the recipe with soy sauce in the amount called for here, and got nothing but complaints about the salt.

Anyway, you could try substituting 2 teaspoons of Worcester for the soy sauce if you find this version too salty. If if then turns out not salty enough for your taste, more Worcestershire, soy sauce, or salt can be added at the table.

I made it the night before, on a busy weekday, came home from work, made some mashed potatoes, and greenbeans, and we were ready to eat in no time. city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I made half this recipe and served it over jasmine rice for a very good dinner.  I used top sirloin steak and cut it into thin strips. After browning the meat, I couldn’t let all those nice browned bits stay behind in the pan, so I deglazed my pan with the tomatoes (I used diced rather than stewed), loosening all that good flavor, and then added it to the slow cooker.  I also added a big clove of minced garlic.  I used a mix of green, red, yellow and orange peppers and added them two hours before the end of the cooking time.  I also added another 1/2 T. corn starch mixed with a little water about 30 minutes before the end of the cooking time to help give the sauce a little more body.  I would make this again, but I think I’d cut back on the cooking time as I think it may not need 6-8 hours on low.  I also would add the peppers about 90 minutes before the end of the cooking time so they would be a bit more crisp tender.

text:
Made this on the stove-top and it was awesome.  I used 2 vidalia onions since we love onions around here.  I also used flank steak which I marinated in a little orange juice, garlic and pepper for a couple of hours before browning (just dry it off first or it will steam instead of brown).  Browned the meat, removed it, sauted the onion and green pepper then deglazed with the liquid (I used beef base instead of boullion).  Covered and cooked on very low about 4 hours.  Meat was tender and delicious.  Served over rice.

country:

text:
Suffers from "Pot Roast-itis". This one (and just about any slow-cooker beef recipe...see my slow cooker Italian Beef review on here...same darn thing) just DOES NOT taste like it's namesake. it mostly comes out to the same thing: a variation on a pot roast.

Now, all that said, of all the "slow cooker beef" recipes I have cooked from Allrecipes or ATK's book, this one did the best at hiding the symptoms of Pot Roast-itis. I love pot roast, just not when it creeps into recipes that aren't supposed to taste like it.

That said, this stuff is delicious...it just is not what is promised/expected. It's very edible (I did the late addition of the peppers, highly recommended...however I wish I would have used half green and half red for that added visual flair. Hot pepper flakes were a worth addition as well).

I want to give this four stars for it's good balance, but at the same time it is so disappointing if you've had "real" pepper steak...so I gave it three. 

Have historically had great luck with Allrecipes 4.5 - 5 star recipes, but lately I have been picking some real duds. I guess the commonality is slow cooked beef!

Anyhow, next time this stuff is going to be made the proper way...fresh, QUICK and in a WOK!

text:
Really great way to have tender beef. I loved it. I have a note for JohnnyD....You can use a dutch oven to make this in your oven or you can use a really big frying pan on your stove top. You won't cook it for hours but you can simmer if for a couple. After your beef is browned, saute your onions and peppers then follow the rest of the recipe and put everyone back in the pan and let it go. Don't lift that lid, just let it go. Hope that helps...Rosie

text:
This was great! They were actually out of top sirloin at Whole Foods, but the butcher (and another customer) said that chuck roast is really all I need for a slow cooker (the customer thought that top sirloin would be overkill). The meat turned out fantastic: very tender and flavorful. The only drawback to using chuck roast, though, is that it tends to be pretty fatty so if you're picky like me you'll spend a lot of time trimming the meat while slicing into strips. I added a lot of garlic powder, and it was delicious.

Simple meal with a lot of flavor. I thought this was very good. I just sprinkled frozen steaks with garlic powder and placed in slow cooker. Then I mixed up bouillon, water, cornstarch, soy sauce, sugar, salt, tomatoes and onion and poured over steaks.  The peppers get pretty mushy, so if you want them more firm, don't add until a couple hours or so into cooking time.  I just cut up steak into strips before serving over rice.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
A good, non-rich solid recipe. I added red pepper flakes, worcestershire sauce, black pepper and red wine vinegar--just a bit of all of them about an hour before it was done. Otherwise, this recipe is a bit bland. DEFINITELY hold off on the peppers till the last 30 minutes--I'm not a huge fan of SUPER crispy veggies, I like them to have the flavor of what they're in, but I don't like them so soft I could gum them if I didn't have teeth. We added one green bell pepper, one red bell pepper 45 mins. before it was done and it was just a touch too soft. Try 30 minutes.  We served with jasmine rice and we all liked it a lot -- no cartwheels, but lots of pleasurable 'mmmmmmm's when eating.

This is FABULOUS! I doubled the sauce and added the peppers toward the end as some other reviewers did. I added a little extra cornstarch as well, as I like thicker sauces. The only other change I made was to use red and yellow bell peppers instead of green, which is just my flavor preference. Other than that I followed the ingredient list to a T and thought the flavor balance was quite nice. Served this over white rice and thought it was a nice change to the all-too-common creamy crock pot recipes. Will definitely make again and maybe play around with the flavors; use teryaki sauce instead of soy sauce perhaps :)

country:

text:
I think this is a great basic recipe.   It's what you do with it that makes all the difference. I am going to make a double batch tomorrow.  I used broth like others, I  sauteed the onion first because I really like mine almost liquefied. Added the peppers the last hour and turned the slow cooker off.  I was not super impressed with the way the flavor was going, so in that last hour, I added garlic, red pepper flakes, seasoned pepper and cumin.  It turned out more like a fajita stew which was fantastic.  My husband had it over brown rice and I topped a salad with it and a little sour cream.  Delish.  I would have given this recipe 5 stars  if I hadn't altered it so much.  My variation was definitely five stars.  Next time I am going to toss in some mushrooms and some fresh tomatoes at the end.

Display Name:
Rayna563

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674136.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I came across this recipe on "the recipe of the day" and I am so GLAD I did!  This dish was wonderful and so easy to make.  Its almost foolproof.  I actually used a center chuck roast I had on hand and just cut it up and seasoned it generously with our favorite steak seasonings.  Also added some worcestershire sauce as others suggested.  I didn't have any beef bouillon cubes so I just used a can of beef broth instead.  Added 2 cans of stewed tomatoes due to having 2.50 lbs of beef. Waiting until the last 45min-hour to put in the peppers (used green and red) gave the peppers the perfect crispness to them.  As other reviewers noted you may have to add a little flour towards the end of cooking to thicken up the sauce.  In the end the meal turned out amazing!  We tried the Pepper Steak over both egg noodles and brown rice.  Loved them both...thanks!

text:
This recipe is very similar to the one my mother used to make. I think hers called for fresh Roma tomatoes vs the stewed ones. I doubled the water, bouillon, cornstarch, soy sauce & sugar but not the salt or tomatoes and it turned out fine. I also added half of the bell pepper in the beginning and the other half during the last hour. This made just the right amount of sauce to serve over brown rice. Definitely a keeper!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Excellent recipe idea!  My personal tweaks are as follows:
spray crockpot with cooking spray
dump in meat (comes precut at my grocery)
season well with lots of garlic powder, some black pepper and generous amount of powdered ginger (this is crucial for authentic peppersteak flavor)
Add 1-2 cans stewed tomatoes, double the soy sauce to 6 tablespoons, skip salt and sugar.
Triple cornstarch to 3 tablespoons mixed into 3/4 cup hot water.  Add while still in suspension.
You can add the onions and peppers (I like large, artistic slices) now or at the end (tastes fine to me either way).
Mix everything up in the crockpot and cook as directed.

text:
I really enjoyed the taste of this recipe.  I did make a few tweaks to it when making it yesterday though.  I didn't bother browning the meat; I added celery; and I kept about half of the peppers out until the last hour (like other reviewers had mentioned).  I also added more cornstarch in that last hour to thicken up the sauce a bit.  I found there was a LOT of sauce, so next time, I'll add more peppers and celery, and maybe add carrots and broccoli as well.  This recipe is being added to my recipe box.
Update:. I made this recipe again a day or two ago, and added about 2 chopped peppers, 2 chopped celery stalks, and bean sprouts about an hour before it was finished.  Loved it!

text:
I made this for the Allrecipes Allstar's crockpot challenge. For anyone who missunderstands this is not Chinese pepper steak. It is a homestyle pepper steak recipe, which is very different. At first bite, I wasn't sure what to think. When it was done the meat was more tender and the vegetables were more soft than I remember pepper steak being. The liquid was also the consistency of water. To thicken it I decided to add 1 1/2 Tblsp. extra of corn starch, when it was finished, and it worked perfectly. I followed the recipe, execpt I used 1 red and 1 green pepper and low sodium soy sauce. It was already plenty salty between the added salt and the canned stewed tomatoes. I would even cut the regular salt back some. I made jasmine rice to go with it. It wasn't a favorite, but worked fine for dinner tonight.

I tried this based on recommendations on the buzz.  It was very good and easy to prepare.  I used precut stir-fry beef strips and used 1 green bell pepper and 1 red bell pepper.  In addition I used no sodium beef bouillon and reduced sodium soy sauce and left out the salt.  Since it had no other asian flavors other than the soy sauce I added 1 tsp minced garlic and 1 tsp ground ginger.  Next time I will add more.  It was very good but did not wow me.  Next time I will add more garlic, ginger, and add a little crushed red pepper.

text:
I gave this recipe four stars because I did make some changes based on the suggestions of other reviewers.  I kept the basic recipe the same, but added two generous splashes of worcestershire sauce.  Also, I replaced one green pepper with a red pepper (also cut my peppers into strips).  I used 5 cloves of garlic minced, and 1/2 an onion cut into strips.  Didn't use any oil to brown the beef.  Finally, I added my peppers during the last thrity minutes and 1 tbsp of cornstarch mixed with a small amount of juice from the crock-pot.  I only cooked it for six hours as well.  Sounds like a lot of changes, but they really made the recipe five stars (at least for me)!

Maybe with some Chinese five spice powder. more garlic, ginger, and some red pepper it would taste a little more like Asian food.  I'm half-Japanese, and just because you add soy sauce to something and serve it with rice, it doesn't make it Asian.  I add soy sauce instead of salt to almost any sauce, and I eat a side of rice almost every day.  That doesn't mean it's Asian food I'm eating...

This recipe was absolutely awesome.  I ate nearly the entire thing by myself.  I hate when I read about changes to a recipe, but I had to out of necesiity because I lacked certain ingredients.

First, I only had filet minon so I used that rather than sirloin.  Also, I had no beef bouillon but my dish was plenty beef tasting so I'm not sure what that adds to the recipe.  Also, I like my sauce a little thicker so I added 2 to 3 tablespoons of cornstarch extras during the cooking process.

FYI, this dish heats up REALLY well the next day and is great over a couple of slices of toast.  Thanks again for the recipe!

I gave this recipe 5 stars because of its potential.  I always make my first attempt exactly as the recipe is written.  Here's what I'll do next time:  Use 3 tbs cornstarch, 6 tblsp soy sauce.  Cook meat 2 hours on low with liquids, seasonings and tomatoes.  Then add peppers (2 green & 1 yellow or red), a large sweet onion, sliced carrots and water chestnuts.  Then cook an additional 2 hours on low.  Thanks Marge!

country:

text:
Other than mediocre pulled pork/chicken, there isn't a slow cooker recipe that I like except for an old family favourite - "Grandma 's Spaghetti".
Until this recipe! 
It lives up to it's high reviews. The aroma is wonderful and with the soy sauce and green pepper ingredients, has a yummy almost Chinese food smell. Arriving home from work everyone said they hoped the dinner that they smelled from the driveway was coming from their kitchen.
This recipe is so good!
* I finally solved the mystery of the auto feature on my slow cooker. If anyone else, who stupidly threw out the box & instructions is wondering, 
when initially set on auto, the temperature will stay at high for 1 hour then will automatically change to low for the remainder of cook time. More than a few sources stated the flavour is remarkably improved.         
Very cool!

text:
I thought this was delicious, and the whole family enjoyed it. The meat was tender, and the sauce was great. However, I would suggest cutting the onions into strips rather than chopping them. Also, don't put the green peppers in from the start or they will turn to mush. Wait until about an hour before it's done to put them in so that they have a little crunch left to them.

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/209339.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Easy to throw together for a "fix it and forget it" type of recipe. I partially froze the sirloin so it was easier to cut it into thin strips.  I didn't use the garlic powder, but rather added minced garlic to the sauce and fried the beef in olive oil vs. vegetable.  I also used a concentrated Swanson flavor packet since I didn't have beef bouillion on hand.  I opted to use a low sodium soy sauce along with a few splashed of low sodium Worchestershire sauce and left the salt out altogether.  To give it a little "kick" I added a tsp. of chili garlic sauce.  I cooked it on high for two hours and an additional 4 hours on low.  I sliced the veggies (onion, green, and red pepper) length wise vs. chopping and added them the last two hours of cooking so they didn't end up mushy.  Perfect served over rice!

text:
We will be having this for supper this week-end.I know it will be good as I have tried similar versions of this before.1 variation I would suggest is to use garlic infused oil instead of the garlic powder and oil for cooking the beef strips.Also,use a packet of Au Jus mix instead of the beef boullion cubes.These will add to the flavor and reduce the work.
( To get the infused oil,just peel some garlic cloves and place in a small jar of Canola or Safflower,olive oil works too.store in the refrigerator until you want to use it.)

text:
Easy, Fast and can prepare most of it the night before. 
Picky husband loved this. Because of my work hours I had to leave it in the cooker for 8 hours, on low. The meat was tender, cut with a spoon and was perfect. I cut my strips  2" wide and about 1/4 thick (strips but not small strips) The peppers- I put the sliced bell peppers on the very top hoping they had a chance - no chance! They were soft but the taste was still good when I placed everything over white rice. Sauce: like others I added core cornstarch mixed with a little water to thicken it up, but it was still a soupy consistency. Regardless, the hubby had two huge servings which is rare! One cooking tip from granny: NEVER tell them how it was "supposed" to turn out!

text:
Pretty good.... I am not a pepper steak fan (or fond of many Asian dishes in general), but this wasn't bad at all. :) Today has been super busy so I needed a meal that required minimal effort to prepare. Of all the recipes that came up in my search, this one jumped out at me. This is perfect for days you don't feel like cooking or have little time to cook a stovetop meal (you can never go wrong slow cooking beef, IMHO). Other than cooking on high for the first hour and adding my bell peppers the last hour of cooking , I made no changes. NOTE: Adding my peppers when I did was spot on. Had I added them any sooner, they would have been mushy. Any later, they'd be too crisp for my liking. Served over rice with a sprinkling of sesame seeds, this was very good. I think I'll try making a sub sandwich with the leftovers tomorrow! Thanks for sharing, MJWAGNER68. :-)

I read through many reviews and took others suggestions and did the following with great success....I marinated the beef in beer overnight.  Then, seasoned it as recipe states, but did not brown in pan, I just put it into crock pot.  I did NOT add extra salt as it was NOT needed due to the soy sauce.  I added a clove or two of minced garlic and some sliced mushrooms.  I used one red pepper and one green, but did not add until last hour of cooking.  Served with rice and had leftovers!!  Will make it again!

userID:

Display Name:
HomeCookinMom
isPro:

followersCount:
0

36
favoritesCount:

recipesCount:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674147.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I had family in from out of town on a weekday.  I saw this recipe and gave it a try.  Crockpot meals while I was at work was an excellent idea.  I purchased a 4 pound sirloin, because I was cooking for ten.  I did the prep work the night before, cut up beef (I did chunks) and peppers and kept separately.  In the morning, I threw together.  I noticed the recipe only called for 1/4 cup of water - I added 2 cups and blended with a good tablespoon of beef base.  I also followed other suggestion of adding peppers in the last hour.  When I got home, my kids thought it was soup!  I turned crockpot on high, added pepers.  When broth simmered, I added the cornstarch and water. Turned into a nice thick gravy within minutes.  Served with rice, salad and fresh bread from market.  Excellent!  I did not have any leftovers (darn!). I will definitely make again!

text:
Very tasty!  You gotta try it!  I made some slight changes and it turned out perfect for me.  I used 2 bouillon cubes, 1/2 cup water, left the onions in rings, petite diced tomatoes, and  brown sugar rather than white, omitted the salt, and then added 1 Tbsp of worcestershire sauce.  I cooked this on high for 3 1/2 hrs and then added the peppers and onions and cooked on LOW for another 30 min so they weren't mushy.  I wish I would have doubled the recipe so I could've had more leftovers!

text:
This is the very, very BEST pepper steak copycat I have ever had at home and takes better than takeout. Buy pre-sliced, pre-tenderized sirloin or tenderize and slice up your own. Add peppers in last and maybe add in 1 tsp cornstarch (blended with 1/2 tsp water) to thicken up sauce and cook for an addition 2 mins. If something is missing, toss in some green onions, but seriously fantastic! Serve with the fried rice recipe on here!!!!

text:
Good and comfortable! I used a 2+lb of chunk roast instead of sirloin. Placed onion and beef slices in the slow cooker. In a measuring cup, mixed the beef broth (1/4cup), 2tsp of arrowroot 1 can diced tomatoes (instead of stewed), 2 tbsp each of soy sauce and worcestershire sauce, thyme, oregano, black pepper, steak seasoning and orange zest. Poured this mixture in the slow cooker and cooked on low for ~8hrs. Stirred in the pepper slices 45min b/f serving. The peppers were perfect.

country:
None
text:
Additional comments:  Made again this time with chuck steak cut into 2" wide strips, doubled the water, boullion, and cornstarch.  Set on low for 8.5 hours.  All the liquid had evaporated except for tiny pools where the chopped tomatoes had ended-up/cooked down to.  Added bell pepper & onion.  This doesn't taste good with chuck steak.  My recommendations:  Don't cook on low all day,' and don't use chuck steak.

11/24/06 Sliced sirloin in 1/2-3/4" wide strips & browned in a drizzle of olive oil.  Topped with a can of chopped tomatoes & sprinkled ingredients atop (omitted salt).  Stirred in sliced onion & bell peppers for last 45" of 3.25 hour cooking on high. Flavourful light/thin sauce.  Veggies were perfect for us--not mushy but cooked soft enough to easily cut with a fork.  A very quick prep and short cooktime (for a slow cooker)!  A very good keeper.

My husband and I both enjoyed this recipe.  The meat was very tender and the sauce was tasty!  I agreed with other reviewers that the peppers were mushy, but when I cook with a slow cooker its because I'm coming home late, and don't have time to add them during the last hour.  I used one red pepper to add color, and had to add extra cornstarch to thicken the sauce, but other wise made no changes.  This is not a recipe that we will be raving about for days, which is why I'm not giving it 5 stars, but it was very good, and I will make it again.

text:
Excellent!  I bought the "sirloin strips for stir-fry" and cooked on high for only an hour and a half and it was delicious!  Meat was cut small enough that it didn't take that long.  It was a bit on the salty side (and I omitted the tsp of salt), but I'm sure a switch to the low sodium broth would help that.  Hubby loved it too!!  (oh, p.s. I used 3 tbsp cornstach & 6tbsp soy sauce per another reviewer's suggestion; the consistency was perfect, but maybe less soy would also lower the sodium content)  Update to original review:  I've made this at least 4 more times since, and it seems like only the first 2 times it came out soooo delish.  The last two times it was just "okay" -- not sure exactly what I'm doing different, but it's apparently one of those recipes that is highly dependent on multiple factors (i.e. cooking times, cut of meat, etc.), so if you loved it, be sure to cook it the same way every time!

text:
This is a  new twist on a recipe I have for Sherried Beef and one for Beef Tips and Gravy. I always use the dry brown gravy mix instead of the bouillon because of the sodium.  I did not put in the sugar and I used red wine instead of water.  Also, as one reviewer did, I used the tomatoes with green chilis.  I also added fresh garlice, carrots and mushrooms.  I used stew meat and sliced it thin.  I only used 1 Tbsp of the cornstarch as the dry gravy mix thickens it on it's own. I also did not brown my meat before.  I served this over mashed potatoes and it was great.  Always served mine over egg noodles and wanted a change. I let it cook for 2 hours before adding the onion, green pepper and carrots.  Next time I will wait a little on the peppers and onions.  I will make this again.

Display Name:
AngelChef

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/2175703.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Made this for dinner tonight and it turned out really well. After slicing,  browning and putting garlic on the steak, I put it in the slow cooker with the other ingredients for about 5 hours on high which allowed the meat (I used filet mignon because we always keep it in the freezer) to tenderize very nicely. As many reviewers suggested, I waited until about 45 minutes until serve time to add the peppers - I used red, orange and yellow ones. Also, I omitted the stewed tomatoes because I was going for a more meaty flavor rather than a tomato-y one. I also quadrupled the water, corn starch and beef bouillon cubes so I would have plenty of gravy. I added a splash of Worcestershire sauce per some reviewers' recommendations. When everything was cooked perfectly tender, I served it over white rice and it was very good. I think that it would turn out just as well using a less costly cut of meat (such as sirloin per the recipe). Also, I would like to figure out how to make the gravy a little more flavorful; I felt like I needed to give it a stronger flavor but I am not sure how to do so.

userID:

Display Name:
DebraMN51

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/1152002.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I should confess that I made a few changes.  First we had leftover grass fed sirloin steak that we grilled the night before.  So I trimmed and sliced it and put it in the crock pot, added grilled sliced onions and covered it in low sodium beef broth (1 1/2 cups) added the ginger, garlic powder, 1 tsp Splenda and low sodium soy sauce and refrigerated it overnight.  In the morning I added the tomatoes and cornstarch (1 TBS dissolved in some of the broth) and turned it on low, then about 45 minutes before serving I added the sliced peppers and turned it on high.  Served over brown rice with a side dish of steamed broccoli. Totally delicious! I was nervous about using grilled steak but the flavor was amazing and it was fork tender.  If you want a thicker sauce add another TBS of cornstarch when you add the bell peppers. No oil, no sugar and low sodium ingredients made this an excellent choice for my hubby who has high cholesterol, high blood pressure, and diabetes.

This is a great dish, I remember from childhood.  I would skip the soy sauce and salt though. The bouillon was plenty salty tasting. Used fresh minced garlic in place of garlic powder. text:
This was good. I must say my husband loved it and I thought it was just good, but will probably make again as it's a nice change from time to time. I followed it exact with the exception of the beef bouillon. I didn't want to use that with the MSG, etc. so I used one little plastic container of the Knorr Homestyle concentrated stock instead that has no additives. This probably also helped cut down on the salt issue that a lot of reviews complained about. Since I didn't use the bouillon I was sure to add some salt as well so that it didn't come out bland (I just used some Montreal steak spice). I served with shanghai noodles instead of rice and that was great.

text:
Wow, this was really delicious. I followed all of the ingredients closely but added an extra red bell pepper I had on hand and used a 28oz can stewed tomatoes just because I love them. I didn't think the extra liquid would make all that much difference but we had too much (flavorful) juice, so in the future I'll not add more total liquid than stated. I made sure to mix the water/bullion/tomatoes etc. in the skillet I browned the meat in, to get all the great browned bits and save a dish. Thanks so much for sharing!

text:
This reminded me of the pepper steak my mom used to make when I was growing up.  It was very easy to make and tasted good too!  I modified the recipe a little and purchased the pre-packaged pepper steak instead of the beef sirloin and just sliced it into thinner strips as they were pretty large pieces.  I did not have the stewed tomatoes so I used diced tomatoes instead.  I also followed another suggestion and cut my red and green peppers into larges pieces instead of chopping them. I used a mixture of red and green to add more color.  If you like a firmer pepper I would add the peppers a little later, although I had no complaints!

userID:
6282819
Display Name:
Carmen Steen
isPro:
False
followersCount:
1
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
5
favoritesCount:
28
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/1219566.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I thought this was great! Not sure about the people who thought it was bland, although I did make a few minor adjustments - I added a tablespoon of Worstershire sauce; we don't use white sugar, so I used brown sugar instead; I added some freshly ground peppers directly to the meat. This is how I layered - sliced peppers (I used 1 each large green and red) and a whole sliced large sweet onion, garlic salt, sliced beef, black pepper and more garlic salt, canned tomatoes (I had diced on hand), then the 1/4 boullion with corn starch. Cooked on high for 3 hours. With 1 hour to go, I noticed the sauce was really thin, so I scooped out enough liquid, let it cool somewhat, and mixed in 2 more tablespoons of corn starch and poured it back in. This thickened the sauce nicely. I'll be making this again, but probably place the beef in whole to keep it from getting so dried out. My husband and 2-year-old son loved it!

region:

country:
None
text:
I continue to search for a GREAT slow cooker meal but have yet to find it.  Here's a tip:  don't cut your beef as thinly as you might for a stir fry dish because mine ended up looking like spanish/cuban ropa vieja (shredded beef).  I cooked this on low for five hours, but I think this may have been done in about three hours.  If you happen to be home, just check on it periodically.  It doesn't taste bad, but I probably won't be making this again.

text:
This was an amazing dish!  I love dishes that you can throw together and forget until later....this one was right up my alley!  I didn't brown the meat before adding it to the slow cooker and didn't see any ill effects because of it.  I also added a few teaspoons of Worst. sauce when I added the soy sauce.  I agree with those of you that said to wait and add the peppers and onion later.  I don't want them too mushy.  I usually add them when it has about 2 hours left.  Thanks for a great recipe.

text:
Just have to give my 2 cents worth to the reviews.  This is one of the best "cook friendly" recipe I have found.  I kept the sauce the same--but doubled it.  I found no need to add other ingredients.  Added vegetable items that needed a better place to be from the fridge.  MOST FOR SURE add the peppers no more than 1 hour before hand.  Cannot believe a slow-cooker recipe is this good--and loved by all.  Add what you want, but this is best left alone.  Forgot to add that instead of corn starch to thicken, I added Wondra flower 1 table spoon at a time until it was as thick as I wanted it to be.  Love Wondra flour---and I don't sell it.

text:
This was AMAZING! I used another reviewer's advice and seasoned the beef with a little bit of Adobo seasoning (with pepper) and added crushed red pepper for a little kick. Also, I omitted the last tsp of salt because there was plenty of salt with the canned tomatoes, soy sauce, and seasoning. My only suggestion is to be very careful with the salt! I served it over minute rice that I cooked in chicken broth. Highly recommend this recipe! Will make it again!!

This was different than i expected, but the meat came out tender and had a pretty good flavor.  I used 1/2 T more cornstarch to thicken up the sauce and sliced the green pepper to make them look pretty.  If you like a firmer pepper, hold off till the last 30 min; I only cooked the peppers for about 35 min on low, and they were more than done.  I also threw in 2 cloves of smashed garlic.  Served with white rice.  Good, just not the pepper steak i was looking for.

I was a little nervous about the tomatoes (I used a can of diced tomatoes), but the prevalent flavor was still the soy sauce (which I wanted).  After it cooked for about 2 hours, the sauce was thick and bubbly, which I liked, but it got much runnier as it kept cooking (maybe from the peppers added at the end?), so I would add 1-2 more Tablespoons of cornstarch next time.  I sliced the onion put in half with the meat, and half with the peppers later.  Put in the peppers at the end for best results (they would probably fully cook in an hour on low).  Overall delicious!  This will be made again!

userID:

Display Name:
Heather

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This was really really good! My husband could not stop eating it! I also bought beef that was already cut up from the grocery store to save some time in the morning. I read quite a few reviews so I would know what to expect and here is what I did. I seasoned the meat very generously with Slap Ya Momma (a cajun seasoning from where I live in Louisiana) and put it straight into the crockpot without browning it. I doubled the bouillion cube and water and I set it on low for about 9 hours (without the peppers) and left for work. When I got home I added a little bit of beef broth to make a little bit more gravy and another tablespoon of cornstarch and a ton more seasoning because it was pretty bland. I continued to let it sit on high until we were ready to eat. When I put the rice cooking that is when I added the peppers, I used green, red and yellow to add color. When the rice was done the peppers were perfect, just the right amount of crunch. Yummy! I will definitely be making this again. Here in Louisiana rice and gravy is a staple at the dinner table, my mother cooked it every night when I was growing up. It was really nice to be able to have something very similar without all the effort and added oils and fats.

I made this tonight for my family. The ONLY variation I made was I was forced to cook it in a low oven ( 250-300)....I added my onions and peppers the last 45 minutes and they kept their consistancy. I also tripled the sauce as we are huge sauce eaters with our rice dishes. All in all it came out great! It's a keeper!! I will make it again and tweak it to mine and my family's personal preferance.

We really enjoyed this recipe. I followed the directions exactly, but added some minced garlic (around 2 tsps. )I cooked it on low for 6 hours, but I think it would have been ready in 5...I took some cool water, added about 1 tsp. cornstarch mixed it together and then put into the pot to thicken the sauce about a half hour before the time was up. I served it over rice and it was delicious! I think next time, I'll only cook for 5 hours and add the peppers about half way through since I do like them soft.Thanks for the recipe.

text:
It's delicious with a few changes. I used 2 cups of low sodium beef broth since I didn't want to add a can of tomatoes (just didn't seem right in the recipe), used a large onion, red bell pepper, no sugar, added worcestershire sauce, low sodium soy sauce and black pepper - it needs pepper. Had to add a little extra cornstarch at the end to get gravy thickness to our liking, absolutely delicious on rice or a cooked potato.

text:
This recipe is yummy!  The flavor is perfect, the meat is extremely tender, and it is easy to put together.  My only alterations- I omitted the salt, put the green peppers in for the last 2 hours to avoid mushy texture, added extra cornstarch at the end and let it sit for another 1/2 hour. I did a slow cook for 6 hours, but it was actually done before then.  I served it over japanese rice.  Next time I'm tempted to add other vegetables (carrots, celery, potatoes).

Display Name:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674167.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Very good, made some changes based on others review. Did not pre cook sirlon, used about 2 1/2 lbs, cut into bit sized chunks. Cut the onion and green pepper in very large pieces and cut up smaller when I thickend the sauce, 30 minutes before eating. Used whole tomatoes crushed up by hand, also increased Boullion cubes to 2, and mixed up in 1/2 cup very hot water, added 6 tbsp of low sodium soy, left out the added salt, added red pepper flakes, small can of green chilies, 3 cloves of crushed garlic, splash of Worcestershire sauce, and fresh ground pepper, came out great. Meat was very tender and peppers were soft but not mushy. Used 3 tbsp Corn starch in 1/2 cup cold water to thicken sauce. Started on high about an hour and finished on low, total cook time about 6 hours. Served over white rice.

I didn't have time one day to make this in the crock pot.  It sounded so good I decided to try a stove top version.  It wasn't as easy as the crock pot method but still worth the little extra effort.  You can cook the vegetables to your liking without them being overcooked as some reviewers reported.  I will definately make it again.  My husband and sons devoured it!  I wouldn't hesitate to make it on the stove again, although would like to try it in the crock pot some day.

So simple & yet sooo good.
I used moose meat.I only had vegie powder broth, but it was good any way. I also used two big quartered onions(we like onion), and 4 garlic bulbs.
Next time (and there will be a next time)I will not add the salt & will add another two peppers(red?) 1/2 way thru the cooking time(the peppers do get very soft, but I think it adds to the flavour). I cooked on high for four hours & served with jasmine rice.

This smells so good as it cooks!  I did as other reviewers suggested and put half the peppers in at the end so they would not be as mushy. Love It! Love It!  Even my picky eater 3 yr old son loved it.  Very easy to make. I didn't have any canned stewed tomatoes, so I got an easy one right off Allrecipes.   I didn't have any sirloin on hand, so I used my top round london broil, cut into strips. Cooked for 2 hours on high, and 4 hours on low.  I did cut down the soy sauce by 1/2 tsp. I served it over rice, and I'm adding this one on the recipe book. It's a true keeper!

Display Name:
Joanne Hoschette

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/6559145.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Too much salt as written There really is no need to add in the 1t.  of  salt, even if using low sodium soy sauce. If you choose to use low sodium soy, keep in mind that sugar is substituted for salt in many low sodium products.  I recommend changing the bouillon to low sodium beef broth, or stock. appx 1 cup ish and then u can skip the water  , . Like many others, I add in more peppers, cut in strips and put them in during the last hour or so
.Sometimes, for a more Italian  version, I like to use Delmonte's diced tomatoes  with basil, oregano, and garlic. & sub the soy for Worcestershire. and a pinch or 2 Italian herb blend. plus a small squirt of tomato paste ( from a tube)  Then serve them on toasted or grilled sub rolls with a slice  of provolone.  Both versions are  very good. Just too much salt in the original  recipe as written.

text:
Very good...so tender and quite easy so I'll make this again for sure! I read the reviews and made adjustments accordingly: I used minced garlic (1 tsp.), reduced the water to 2 Tbsp because I used a 19 oz can of diced tomatoes, besides the green pepper I added 1/2 of a red pepper, omitted the salt adding ground black pepper, and then I increased the cornstarch to a heaping tablespoon. In the end,  the sauce was just the right consistency and went very well with the wild rice served with it. Yum!

oxifresh

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614242.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This was very good, and we enjoy this any time of the year over some rice.  To offset the saltiness many have commented about,  I used low sodium broth (boullion) & low sodium soy sauce, as they are both very salty on their own, and omitted the 1 t salt. I did not brown the meat first - just another pan to clean, and this step is not necessary.  I also put 3-4 slices of bell pepper in the beginning, then add the rest during the last hour of cooking so at least the flavoring is evident during the entire cook time, but you eliminate the mushy peppers when serving.  Awesome recipe!

country:
None
text:
Great recipe! I had bottom round so I used that,  cut instead into 1" strips. I seasoned it with Montreal steak seasinong while browning. 
Since I was out of soy sauce, I used 2 Tbsp A1 and 2Tbsp worcestershire sauce instead. I also used double the amount of peppers, a combo of red, green and yellow.  
I would suggest waiting to add the peppers until you have only 1 1/2-2 hours of cooking time left. That's what I did and they bordered on being overcooked. I can only imagine the peppers completely breaking down if you add them at the beginning.
This was fantastic and my family absolutely LOVED it--22 month old, 14 year old and husband devoured it, speaking their praise in grunts of satisfaction. I will be making this again.

country:

text:
1/2 tsp chilli peppers, 1/2 tsp ginger, 1 tbsp not real minced garlic, 1 medium chopped onion, added no salt, 1 tsp naturally brewed soy sauce, 1 tsp Worcestershire sauce, used a 2.4 pound sirloin roast,1 tsp 25% less salt Bovril Beef liquid concentrate added to 1/4 cup hot water.  I added the green peppers for the last hour 15 mins. Thickened with 2 tbsp so cornstarch I also browned my meat removed added onion and garlic cooked 2 mins more.  Cooked for 6 hours on low.  This was really good served it over rice.

userID:
5249656
Display Name:
stephgaff
isPro:
False
followersCount:
0
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
4
favoritesCount:
30
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674154.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is a very good recipe and freezes nicely as well. Here is how I do it. Its very important to get good meat for this. I usually get a high quality chuck roast. I trim and slice it into 1.5 in chucks. I sear the beef with olive oil, fresh garlic, red wine, salt and pepper. Transfer to crock pot then add stewed tomatoes, bouillon/cornstarch mixture, soy sauce, dash of Worcestershire, sugar, half a bag of chopped frozen onions, and more spices (garlic powder, oregano, dried parsley, black pepper). Let this cook on low for 5/6 hours. THEN I add a bag of frozen mixed pepper strips and sometimes I need a little more cornstarch depending on how thick it is. Turn up to high for 1 hr. Done! Very yummy!
Review:
Rating:
5

Added about 2-3 tablespoons of coarse cracked peppercorns (bell peppers don't make this a pepper steak!) and used stew meat instead of strips of sirloin. Literally, one of the best things I've ever put in my mouth. add a TON of cracked pepper and it just mingles so nicely with the savory flavors in the soy sauce, stewed tomatoes, and beefy flavor.

Made the recipes as written. Everyone loved it. My picky 8 year old who had previously never liked pepper steak had 2 1/2 helpings! It's a new favorite for her. I prepped the beef & other ingredients the night before, there it all in the crock pot before work & set it for 6 hours on low. Easy peasy! Otherwise, it's perfect and easy!

userID:
731723
Display Name:
SZYQ1
isPro:

61

recipesCount:

reviewsCount:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/4049308.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I cooked this dish on high for 3 hours and then low for 2 hours (added the bell peppers for the last two hours of cooking to avoid soggy peppers). The beef was a little tough, but the next day it was very soft and tender. The peppers and tomatoes tasted fine with the beef. This recipe is more of a basic beef stew (more like a basic beef soup with unnecessary soy sauce in it, which cannot be tasted at all in this dish). It does not smell bad as noted by other reviewers, and is edible. This dish overall tastes OK, but is not great--on the bland side and in need of more ingredients. Hence, I'm only rating this 2 stars for a stew/soup type of recipe. For the outcome of this recipe being very soupy and bland in taste, you would have time better spent making a different actual beef stew type of recipe.

For the reviewers looking for a pepper steak type of recipe you would find at a Chinese restaurant, don't try slow cooking it! Stir fry your ingredients using fresh garlic and ginger, scallions/onions, soy sauce, and maybe even some dry sherry. If you want to add in tomatoes, cut up a few fresh to add to your stir fry along with a little bit of sugar. Don't forget the black pepper too!

text:
Because this recipe has limited spices and other ingredients the piece of steak you choose must be a nice piece of sirloin since the meat is the STAR of this recipe. I always prefer freshly roasted garlic in olive oil and I splashed some liquid smoke into the crock pot. Served over jasmine rice with a nice dry wine a salad and some crusty bread and you have a great easy meal. If you invest in a good sirloin this cooking method will produce a very tender beef dish. I will make this again!

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614250.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
One of my fav recipes. I do change a few things.
I use a chuck roast. Just put it in to the crock pot instead of browning anything. Less for me to wash, the better.
I also use chopped garlic instead of powder. I add in a little bit more bouillon than needed and don't bother with the water (I use the liquid bouillon). I just dissolve it in the can of tomatoes.
Whole onion, no sugar (it's not needed), no cornstarch, and a couple more bell peppers. Nothing too drastic that would change the flavor really. Delicious!!! Best served over some rice and has lots of juice for extra deliciousness.

Display Name:
Karen Martin

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/global/features/190.gif
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This did not turn out well for me.  I prepared it as written.  My first issue was browning the beef.  I know that it adds flavor, but when I make something in the crock pot, I don't want to cook everything first.  By the time I was done browning, I could have just thrown in the peppers and onions and had it done in 20 min.  I cooked on low for 6 hours.  By the time it was done, the peppers were disintegrating and the beef was no longer strips, it was shredded.  The flavor was very bland.  I had to add a good glug of soy sauce to give it ANY flavor at all.  I had to add more cornstarch to thicken, and by the time I was done, I pretty much had stew.  Only not very tasty stew.  I won't make this again.

city:

None
country:
None
text:
Was a hit with friends and family! In order to make it a five star recipe, I recommend mincing fresh garlic rather than using powder, don't add the salt- definitely enough with the soy sauce and bouillon. One of the best bits of cooking advice I received is you can always add but you can't subtract, so add your seasonings a little at a time and taste your food to see if you need more.  Add the peppers towards the end of cooking otherwise they are way too mushy. I did use both red and green peppers for more color. I also added a dash of sesame oil and some cayenne pepper for a little more flavor and kick. Served over rice and friends and family were very happy!

Display Name:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674164.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I have mixed feelings on this. While the flavor is good, I dont find the texture of the meat pleasing. As most others recommended, I didnt throw the peppers in untill the last 30 minutes or so, and the onion about an hour earlier. I use strips of pepper, along with larger "ribbons" of onion. However, cooking the meat that long breaks it down far to much for my taste, almost like a shreaded beef. I've made this a few times, and still have yet to find a good balance of cooking time, and still giving the sauce a good flavor. I actually find quick cooking this in a wok to work a lot better, and gives it a fresher overall feel.

Very easy!  Used almost an entire yellow onion, 1 green and 1 red pepper.  Also opted to pass on the teaspoon salt due to concerns about saltiness from soy sauce.  Sauteed sirloin in only 1 tblsp. vegetable oil, again due to my personal need to watch fats.

Overall an easy and filling meal!

text:
Made with a few modifications, and this was delicious.  First, I did not brown the meat before adding to the slow cooker.  It was so tender and delicious that this step wasn't missed.  Used mostly red wine & a little hot water for the bouillon, fresh garlic, and replaced 1 tbsp of soy sauce with Worcestershire.  As per the advice of numerous reviewers, peppers were added about 1.5 hrs before serving & were still plenty soft.  Very tasty & simple!

text:
Although I haven't tried this recipe for Pepper Steak, I know it's good because I have been using a recipe given to me by (working chefs) family members, and it's very similar.  The only exceptions are:  you can use any type of beef you want, tomato puree, worcestershire, beef broth, canned Chinese vegetables and canned mushrooms (you can add fresh if desired).  
It takes a little time to balance the sauce(soy, worcestershire and puree) which is later thickened with a cornstarch slurry.

text:
This was an excellent recipe from which to improvise.  I used beef stew meat instead of sirloin because it was much cheaper.  I used both garlic powder and fresh minced garlic.  I added a splash of worcestershire sauce, both a red and a green pepper.  I added the peppers 1/2 way through the cooking, but would add them 3/4 through next time.  Added pineapple right at the end.  Also used ginger.  served on garlic mashed potatoes.  The entire family loved it.  Made much more than 6 servings.

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674134.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This recipe is fantastic and super easy. I made it for the first time this weekend for a dinner party of 20 people as an extra meat dish. I used top round, cut into small chunks. I cooked on low for nearly 10 hours.  The meat was very tender and the flavors were awesome with no modifications necessary.  I did use fresh chopped garlic, lite soy sauce, and marinated the meat overnight in a bit of lite soy.  Like others, I put the peppers in only 30 minutes before serving time, and they were perfect - soft but not falling apart.  I served with rice and egg noodles.  I received rave reviews, many likened it to more of a goulash than a pepper steak, probably because of the tomatoes.  Will make again!

text:
Delicious! I used some black pepper marinated sirloins that we bought awhile back but didn't really care for because they were a little tough. They were tender and delicious after using them in this recipe! I used a whole onion and 2 1/2 large green peppers. I added the peppers half way through. I also added 1/2 cup of water in the beginning, so I needed to add a little more cornstarch. There was a good amount of "gravy" at the end and was perfect served over plain white rice. Thank you for a great recipe!

One word - Delish!  Served this on bulky sub rolls for dinner last night with provolone cheese.  The flavor was awesome and the meat was so tender.  Only changes I made were:  I used a whole chopped onion, used a red, green and yellow pepper, used a can of chopped tomatoes and omitted the salt.  I did not brown the meat, just placed in the slow cooker turned on HI for the first hour, then turned to LOW for the remaining cooking time.  I also did not put the peppers in until one hour prior to serving.  Will defnitely make this again.

This was fantastic!  I cooked it on low for 7 hours.  It needed more broth, the top meat was either dried out or still tough. text:
I left this on low for 10 hours, adding cut up green and red peppers 3 hrs before serving (next time, I'd cut that down to about 1-1/2 hrs). The salt amounts seemed high for me, so I halved the amount of soy sauce, and omitted the extra tsp salt. I served this over brown rice, and topped it with a sprinkling of dry roasted peanuts. Everyone liked this.
Sept 2014: Made this again, using cheaper, cut-up stewing beef. Added the green peppers an hour before serving, as many other reviewers have also recommended. Half the soy sauce, no extra salt, and added a tsp of Worcestershire Sauce. Great taste again !

Yum, delish!!  Following other reviews, I added the green peppers in an hour before it was time to take it out. After the meal was done, I scooped out about 1/2 cup of the juice, and added cornstarch to it, then back in the pot to thicken up the liquid, so it would be a nice gravy over my egg noodles.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This beginner cook who likes experimenting has found a keeper! I altered the ingredients a bit and love the result.  Doubled the bouillon, water and soy sauce for more sauce.  Instead of six tablespoons of soy sauce, I substituted 2 tablespoons with worcestershire to cut down on the salt.  Also, I didn't add salt - soy sauce is salty enough for us.  Brown sugar instead of white.  And added crushed black pepper with the garlic powder before browning.  Like other posters have suggested, I waited to add the peppers in the last two hours.  Plus, added broccoli florets at the same time.  I don't like peppers and the broccoli was a nice addition for my taste.  The only thing I would do different next time is to allow for the full cooking time.  I tried cooking on low for 5 1/2 hours and the meat wasn't as tender as it could have been.

text:
I followed this recipe exactly except I followed advice from others and added the chopped pepper during the last hour of cooking. There wasn't a lot of sauce at this point and it was very runny so I followed some more advice and added a full can of beef broth and more cornstarch. This helped the look of the dish but then I tasted the sauce and noticed it was very very bland. So I followed another reviewers advice and added worcestershire sauce, which didn't go at all. I then added a splash of red wine hoping that would help and that didn't either. I am giving this 2 stars only because my husband didn't think it was completely awful but he doesn't want me to ever make it again. I didn't care for it even before all the changes I made and was very disappointed considering the amount of great reviews this got. My husband and I ate just enough to not be hungry anymore. Huge waste of money!

I have made this several different ways depending on what ingredients I have in the house at the time.  I usually just make it in a combination frypan/sauce pan and do not use a slow cooker.  I usually double the soy sauce and sugar.  Sometimes I used crushed tomatoes instead of stewed because my husband does not like chunks of vegetables.  Also I do chop the green/red peppers so they disappear into the sauce for the same reason.  I am sure this would work with children too...what they don't know can't hurt them!

text:
This was absolutely delicious. It is so refreshing to find a slow cooker recipe that doesn't involve stockpiling mountains of "cream of something soup". I didn't have any beef so I used pork and I didn't have any garlic powder so I just used fresh garlic. I doubled the recipe and substitted the second lot of soy for sweet soy. I also added some worchestershire and a heap of black pepper as other reviewers suggested. After reading another reviewers comment, I was hesitant about adding two cans of tomato, but found that they almost completely disapeared. I also waited till the final hour to add the peppers. All in all this was a great recipe that I will be making again and again! Thank you!

text:
My three star rating for this recipe is based on several changes/additions that I made.  Like some other reviewers, I added the pepper last and used beef broth (1/2 cup).  I also added a couple of pinches of ginger and some leftover roasted red peppers I had on hand.  I didn't brown the meat and I used fresh minced garlic.  I thought these changes would improve the dish, but my husband didn't care for it at all.  He gave it a 2.5.  I didn't think it was that bad and the meat was really tender, so I gave it a 3.  It just didn't have the flavor we were hoping for.  It wasn't a waste, but I probably won't make again.

This was just OK.  One thing that could be changed was to not use sirloin in the crockpot.  The meat fell apart with a couple of turns of the spoon.  The crockpot works so well with cheap cuts of meat.  Why not use stew meat?  The other problem I had with this recipe was a lack of flavor.  I had to dress up the sauce with red pepper flakes, ginger, and another teaspoon of sugar.  After these adjustments, it may have earned a 4, so,   I will try it again.

text:
When reading the ingredients initially I remember thinking that this did not sound like what I think of as pepper steak. When I think pepper steak, I think chinese food.   Well..I decided to give it a try anyway, and I am glad I did, because it was good..I just didn't think it was fantastic. I only rated 3 stars because if you follow the directions on cooking times you will wind up with a big pot of mush. I even used round steak instead of sirlion (because of it being more economical when feeding a family of 5) and thought that since it was round steak it would be fine cooking a bit longer, but it was overcooked.

I personally like to use my crock pot for meals I can put together in the pot and forget about it until the end of the day. This is not one of those kinds of meals.

Pretty good -- I took others advice and added peppers in two stages -- some near then end.  I only had beef round steak in my freezer, so thawed it and cut it into strips.  I was a little worried that it would be tough and chewy in the crockpot, but it was actually wonderfully tender.  Even the kids had no trouble chewing it up.  Older son and husband absolutely inhaled this -- although husband asked for more "gravy" next time.  I may add more broth and thicken with cornstarch near the end when I make this again.  Thanks for a new, easy dinner idea!

text:
My husband really liked this one.  As suggested by others, I used 3 tablespoons cornstarch and 6 tablespoons soy sauce.  I skipped the browning step and the salt and added just 1 green pepper toward the end of the cooking time.  To avoid mushy meat, do not overcook!  In fact, I found this doesn't even need the length of cooking stated in the recipe.  Smells wonderful as it cooks and, served over rice, is delicious comfort food.

text:
This was very good.  I read the reviews first and made some changes.   I used moose meat, I'm not allowed to buy beef when my hubby brings home the "moose"!!  Can't even tell the difference anyway!!! I didn't pre-cook the meat, don't really need to.  I also added 1 can of beef broth which meant I had to double the cornstarch.  It still could have used a little more cornstarch.  Also added the peppers the last 1-2 hours before it was ready.  Cooked on high in a 4 quart slow cooker for 4 1/2 hours.  Very yummy, even picky kids loved it.  Served over egg noodles.   Michele, Ontario, canada

After having this pepper steak at my daughter's home (KarenHeaslip), I had to make it. userID:
14786042
Display Name:
Bobbie
isPro:

1

reviewsCount:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614261.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
The stewed tomatoes in this recipe seemed a surprise ingredient for pepper steak which in my opinion is Asian.  I almost decided to leave them out.  So glad I didn't!  We loved this, though I had a few adaptations.  I used beef broth rather than bullion and water.  Mixed the cornstarch into that.  I also used a London Broil I'd gotten on sale and cut it into smaller width strips.  It browned quickly and I added the ingredients, except salt (not sure why it's called for with bullion and soy, both of which are salty).  I followed another reviewer's suggestion to add 1/2 t grated ginger and a splash of Worcestershire.  I also waited to add the peppers until about the last hour, as we prefer firmer veggies.  My cooker may run warmer than others or perhaps because my beef strips were thinner, in 4 hours on low this was truly ready!  I served over rice and added a few chow mein noodles on the top for crunch.  Next time I might try toasted sesame seeds.  Thanks MJWAGNER68 for a real keeper of a recipe.  I think either chicken or pork would be great cooked like this.
Review:
Rating:
4

2019-10-27T15:28:47.213

text:
I made the changes that others suggested:  use red and yellow peppers vs green, omit salt, reduce soy sauce by 1 tablespoon,  add 1 tablespoon of Worcestershire sauce, and, at the end add 2 more tablespoons of cornstarch to some of the juice and mix in to create the final product.  I also did what other said and added the peppers later.  I cooked on high for 2 hours, added peppers, and then cooked on high for 2 more hours.  My family said it tasted almost like sweet and sour beef...but not really. Ha!  Regardless, they loved it and asked for it again!

text:
This dish had a very nice taste but I believe it could have been better if it had not cooked so long. In the crock pot my meat just fell apart instead of remaining in it's strip style. It was a little on the salty side. I made this recipe just as it was written and I will make it again but with some adjustments. For one, once I sprinkle the meat with garlic powder, it will go into the crock without making it to the skillet. Sirloin is not cheap and it doesn't take so many hours to cook. It will be cooked for about 2 hours and no more. It doesn't need to go into a crock pot because it is not a tough cut of meat so I'll cook it on the stovetop instead. I served it on top of rice, which was a nice compliment.

text:
My husband and son are hunters, so I'm continually looking for recipes I can adapt for wild game. I tried this with venison (not even the best cuts) and it was great! The meat was fork-tender and not at all strong tasting. I let it cook on low all day while we were at work, so it was longer than suggested. The flavors were well balanced and slightly asian-y. I served it over basmati rice, with a side of salad. I'm sure it would be delicious with beef also. I will definitely make this again.

userID:

Display Name:
Ashfat
isPro:

followersCount:

reviewsCount:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614246.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Well I made this recipe but because my t-bone steak, which I used, turned out dry,  I discovered another recipe by altering this one a bit.  I ended up making the best soup my husband ever had.   
 Now I leave the steak whole while it cooks. Since I don’t have the bouillon cube or cornstarch, I add a heaping tablespoon of gravey mix to the 1/4 cup of water.  Omit the salt.  Everything else is the same.

When it was all done in the slow cooker, I take out the steak and chopped it in cubes, add chicken broth and some Worcestershire sauce, a can of potatoes diced and voila, a beautiful hearty soup for winter.

I have actually made this recipe 3 times now (forgot to rate and write a review - sorry!).  I love this recipe and every time I make it, I get rave reviews from the family. I love making recipes that I find on Allrecipes and the family tells me "You should actually look into becoming a professional cook" and I am thinking to myself is "All I am doing is following the directions/instructions on the recipe". Thanks for making me look like a professional CHEF! :-)

text:
Has such a good flavor and easy to throw in the crockpot in the morning. I did not use salt, since soy sauce is already pretty salty. I added a couple dashes of worchester sauce, and seasoned the beef with garlic powder and black pepper. I substituted fresh diced Roma tomatoes with a dash of ketchup, since I didn’t have any canned ones on hand. I prefer my peppers soft, and I think it gives the meat a nice flavor, so I added mine at the beginning. I also used red and yellow peppers and it was still delicious. This will be a staple in our house.

userID:
18260048
Display Name:
Patricia Brune
isPro:
False
followersCount:
0
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
8
favoritesCount:
41
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/4406040.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This will be a regular in my rotation. The flavors are reminiscent of the stir-fry version of pepper steak, but blended so deliciously with the tomatoes, and the meat is tender. I was relieved, however, to have followed my instincts and drastically reduced the amount of sodium. 

My modifications included  no-salt added stewed tomatoes, 2 TBS of low sodium soy sauce, no additional salt, no sugar, and I made the slurry using Better Than Bouillon (taste preference) instead of a cube. I like to bulk up a recipe with extra vegetables so I used three ribs of sliced celery, which complimented the flavors nicely. As for the sugar - I saw no need for it, the cooked peppers provide plenty of sweet. It was plenty salty enough - next time I will go down to 1.5 TBS of soy sauce or maybe even substitute coconut aminos. Served it with mashed sweet potatoes. It doesn't get much more comforting than that!

Note for Instant Pot cooks -the slow cooker function on medium for 2.5 hours was perfect timing.
Review:
Rating:
5

userID:
1074761
Display Name:
Rolanda
isPro:
False
followersCount:
27
followingCount:

madeRecipesCount:
33
favoritesCount:

recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/6051834.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
DO NOT put the peppers in with all of the ingredients.  Add the peppers during the last hour otherwise you will have green and red mush. (I use red and green)  Once I add the peppers, I take a little broth out and mix in a cup with 1-2TBL of cornstarch (until there are no lumps) to thicken the sauce.  I prefer a  thicker sauce, especially, when serving over rice.  If you use the cut of meat the recipe calls for it will taste good and since it's being slow cooked, the meat will not be tough.  However, one time I used sirloin the steak and it tasted amazing versus just good.  Of course it's more expensive but there was a big difference in taste.  My son really likes this.
Review:
Rating:
5
dateLastModified:
2017-09-14T13:02:32.707
helpfulCount:
0

text:
This is a FABULOUS dish, and so easy to make!

I departed from as printed by using home-made stewed tomatoes, which were pretty sweet, so I did not add more sugar.  We LOVE peppers, so used six medium sized ones, just cut into quarters.  For beef, I used a London Broil cut cross-grain in 3/8" strips.  I did add the peppers later so they were firmer - 
Loved it, and am making it again today!

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is very good. I used thick cut sirloin steak with very little fat on it. I'm not a big fan of green peppers, I like red/ orange/ yellow peppers better. Since I had an orange and yellow pepper I needed to use, I decided to do both of those along with one green pepper. Based on reviews I did add an extra Tbls of cornstarch mixed with a Tbls of water in the last hour to thicken the sauce some. I also added the peppers with 2 hours left. They came out very soft but not mushy. However, if you like crisp peppers I would add them in the last hour. I ate this with brown rice. Will make again!

text:
This meal was great! We used a quinoa blend instead of rice as our starch because that was all we had to put this pepper steak on and even my son ate some of it (considering he doesn't eat much of anything that is amazing).  I made this in an instant pot and cooked the meat for 20 minutes, then added the veggies for 5 minutes.  The veggies were a little soft, so I will only go for 3 minutes next time.  Also, to save money I bought Tender Chuck Steak instead of sirloin.  I cut it across the grain and it was fork tender.  All in all, this recipe cooked in the instant pot, will become a regular in our menu.

text:
I doubled the meat, used one green, one orange, and one yellow bell pepper, cut the stewed tomatoes up so they'd be distributed a little better, and added a little more cornstarch to thicken the sauce a bit more, so it would cling to the rice, and instead of the bullion cube, used "Better than Bullion" soup base. I used steamed Jasmine Rice (our favorite rice), and then also made a side of green beans with butter, pasta and salad elegance, and some real bacon bits. This was delicious, and we're all looking forward to the leftovers for tomorrow.

TyThe Prettyblk Barbie

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/3928262.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I made this dish and I loved it.  I used all of the spices recommended and added onion powder and steak seasoning. I found the secret to this dish was the soy sauce. Once adding in the corn starch it makes it a little bland, so I added a few more tablespoons to put more flavor back into the dish. Don't over due the cornstarch either, it takes away the flavor  plus it thickens as you leave it in the crock pot.  Overall, I think this was a good easy quick dish (I left in the crock pot for 4 hours). Its also pretty kid friendly too, my son ate the steak and left the rice. Would probably work over mashed potatoes as well.
