I made the recipe as is, but while the meat was tender and delicious, the green peppers took on a bitter, mushy flavor / texture and might be better served with a red pepper and a yellow pepper. Likewise, while the onion was ok, I've recently found that yellow onions do a little better than white onions in recipes of this nature. It didn't help that we aren't huge tomato fans, admittedly, but I will likely use this as a base and modify the vegetable and sauce contents.

I subbed Worcestershire for soy sauce. I used flour instead of corn starch since I did not have any of these ingredients. Therefore, I omitted the sugar and the salt since my substitutes had them. I also sliced up 2 garlic cloves and added with the vegetables. I cooked on high for 3 hrs. I did need to make a flour slurry with the slow cooked liquid that I added 15 minutes before  serving.  It was a big hit. Will definitely make this again.

I will  most definitely make this again! 
This turned out absolutely delicious served over rice. I chose to cook on low for 6 hours and the meat melted in your mouth. I did cut the green peppers into strips, and following another reviewer's recommendation I waited to put them in one (1) hour before serving.  It turned out perfectly as the peppers were still crisp.  I also added more water /  corn starch mixture and stired it in 30 minutes before serving to thicken up the  liquid which other reviewers mentioned and it made a very nice gravy over the rice.

I made this tonight.  Listened to other reviewers who recommended adding worcestershire sauce, more soy sauce and subbing brown sugar for the white.  I also added hot sauce and did not add sugar.  I made the mistake of not doubling the corn starch as recommended and will do so in the future.  The sauce was very tasty but thin.  Very easy recipe for a good hearty meal.  Will make again.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
It was okay as written. I didn't add salt. I did made it using a top round London Broil cut. It lacked a lot of flavor. I added a few minced cloves of garlic, about a tsp of rice vinegar (apple cider would work), a tsp of mirin (sherry would work), a pinch of crushed red pepper, 1/2 - 3/4 tsp ground ginger, 1 tbs Worcestershire and 1 tbs oyster sauce (Maggi or Kitchen Bouquet would work). I also had to increase the soy sauce to 4 tbs, the veg oil to sesame oil, the onion to 1 full cup, the white sugar to brown sugar and the water + cornstarch mixture to 1 c and 3 tbs to make it appropriately thick.

Display Name:
mauragolf2

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674154.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
My mother used to make a recipe similar to this and it had been on my mind for quite a while to try and find a recipe similar.  I found this and was not disappointed.  I added 3 stalks of celery (cut into 1/2" slices) for the last hour of cooking and then a can of water chestnuts for the last 1/2 hour.  I also used Top Round instead of sirloin and it was so tender you could cut it with a fork.
*** By slicing and browning the meat, I found that the cook time on "low" actually only took 4 hours.  I cooked it for 6 hours but it made the meat break apart like a brisket.  I recommend cooking on low for 3 hours, adding the celery for the last hour and then adding the water chestnuts for the last half hour.***

This was actually pretty fantastic. However, the one change I would make next time is not to add the peppers until there's an hour or less left. When they cook for four hours they basically dissolve, leaving the skins behind.
Oh, and I used beef stock in place of the bullion cube because of the "too salty" comments. It was great! I had a rice bowl for dinner for several nights.

Way too many modifications needed to make this good. Between the soggy veggies, the liquidified "gravy" and the lack of grounded pepper in pepper steak this was ok at best. I'm noticing a ton of modifications done in the comments as well but still people give the recipe a 5 star when you have to change half of the recipe. A five star recipe means nothing needed to be changed or added. The rating on this site in general is super misleading.

text:
This is great!   I used a lean sirloin steak, added carrots cut into strips, and used lots of  fresh garlic instead of powered.  Also used low sodium soy and only a half cube of bouillon to cut down on the salt, and it was still outstanding. Served it over brown rice with a side of garlic & butter sauteed mushrooms, w/ a nice pinot noir.  Great meal.  Def. put in the peppers the last 45 min or so and they'll be cooked perfectly.  A worthy add to the dinner rotation.

I've been making this dish for 2 years. My family absolutely loves it. My daughter actually said to me,"This gets better every time you make it!" It's one of my "go to" meals along side slow cooker sweet and sour chicken. I keep a few cans of stewed tomatoes in my pantry and always have a few pounds of stake in my freezer. All I need to purchase at the grocery store is an onion since all the other ingredients I consisting have on hand. I HIGHLY recommend serving this over jasmine rice. This recipe is incredibly easy and delicious....I hope ur family enjoys it as much as mine!!! :)

OK this was a trial and error recipe for me.  I originally bought steaks, and sliced them into strips and followed the recipe, and what a disaster.  Toughest strips of meat ever.  I tried it again with pre cut stew meat, and it was so tender and wonderful.  The second time I tripled the peppers using red/green/orange bell peppers, and doubled the onion because, well because I love vegetables.  The more the merrier.  I couldn't get my sauce to thicken up, but honestly I was okay with it just the way it was over rice.  My husband loved it too.

This is a great recipe.  I made some substitutions to make it more paleo - used liquid aminos instead of soy sauce, omitted the sugar and lightened up the salt.  Try using tenderized round steak instead of sirloin - cut it across the grain into strips.  Serve over zucchini noodles instead of pasta or rice.  Deelish!

text:
This is a great go to recipe.  My family is very picky and thought they may not like it.  They loved it and said it was a keeper.  So easy to fix with rice on a busy day.  I did cut the soy sauce in half so that it would not be too spicy.  I also used 1 each of the red, yellow and orange peppers to give color. Increased the sugar to 1 tablespoon to counteract the acid in the tomatoes.  All in all great flavor!

My family of 4 loved this meal! I did change a few things though based on other reviews. I omitted the salt & the peppers (since my fam doesn't care for them), added a couple cloves of fresh garlic, a couple splashes of Worcestershire & a little red pepper flakes for a kick. Oh & I didn't have stewed tomatoes on hand so I used diced tomatoes with green chilies instead. So, I guess I changed it quite a bit but it was perfect! This reminded me of a pot roast so I made it along with whipped garlic mashed potatoes, fresh green beans & a caesar salad! So good!

Very good! I tripled the sauce ingredients so that we'd have plenty for rice or egg noodles and added lots of minced garlic and some red pepper flakes. Really good recipe. I didn't have time to make my "go to" recipe for pepper steak, but this was a good alternative.  Doubled the meat (large family), and tripled the sauce.  Added the peppers towards the end (per reviews)and added more onion (personal preference). I omitted the salt because the soy sauce is so salty! Only addition I made was to add ground ginger. I will add this to my list of slow cooker recipes!

text:
Great recipe!  I modified it slightly to add crushed red pepper and minced garlic for additional flavor.  Also used the low-sodium soy sauce so it wasn't overly salty.  I cooked it on high for 3.5 hours and added the peppers with about an hour remaining.  The peppers were soft, but not mushy, and the steak was very easy to pull apart, but not overly stringy.

userID:
2987017
Display Name:
erica3639
isPro:
False
followersCount:
0
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
6
favoritesCount:

recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/262581.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I used thin sliced petite sirloin steak for this, and had it seasoned at the store with a garlic based steak type seasoning. I told the butcher what I was making and he recommended that. It reminded me of Montreal Steak Seasoning, but with a more garlic base to it. I used olive oil instead of vegetable oil and then once the meat was browned, drained it in a strainer. I left out the tomatoes, salt and soy sauce. I instead made more of the beef base, using Better Than Bullion for it, and then added a bit if Mrs. Dash garlic and herb seasoning. I then added mushrooms, celery and a bit of cilantro into it. Instead of just using green bell peppers, I used the green but added some red, yellow and orange peppers too. Once it was in the croc pot, I taste tested the sauce and added more sugar or Mrs. Dash as needed, and it has a great flavor, without being too salty. I served it over Jasmine rice and my family loved it!
Review:

5

text:
LOVED this! I also bought pre cut stir fry strips.  It was only a pound and a half so I used one bell pepper only.  I also used stewed tomatoes with jalapenos which gave it a little zing (it was still pretty mild).  I cooked on low for about 6 hours.  I added another tbsp of cornstarch disolved in water the last half hour to thicken it up a bit and also decided at that point I wanted some more veggies. So I microwaved a steam fresh bag of broccoli and threw it in.  Noone was home early enough to add the bell peppers and onion in a couple hours before so I added them in the beginning.  They were very soft. I would have preferred to throw them in later but it didn't take away from this great recipe. The beef was super tender and it was very tasty. I served it over quinoa.

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/3274570.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Delicious recipe!  I did switch up part of the cooking method just a bit.  We were out for the day and I knew the peppers would be too soft if I had them go in with the meat.  We like them to be on the crisp side so, I prepared the meat and assembled everything but the peppers and onions and let that cook. (I also tossed in 2 whole Long hot peppers for some heat) The day before I made the bell peppers and onions with fresh garlic but made a lot more that called for because we like it heavy on the Veggie side. Sat that aside in the fridge. When we got home I added the veggies to the meat in the crock pot to heat through.  By the time the table was set the rice was cooked and it all came together quickly.  The veggies stayed crisp and the meat was tender.  Good recipe but we would like it with a little more sauce next time. Will make again.

Display Name:
Bassfayce

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674134.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Prepared exactly as per the recipe, except for not pre browning the beef, using low sodium soy sauce, and omitting the salt, as others suggested. I never knew food could be both salty AND bland! When it should have been done cooking, i tried to "doctor" it as others suggested, adding worschester sauce and more peppers after 5 hours of cooking on low (when the beef was not yet tender), adding some mirin (Japanese sweet sake for cooking) and none of that helped. Eventually I had to rescue the expensive almost all organic ingredients I almost wasted on this recipe by turning it into another dish, Filipino "mechado"...(added 4 small quartered potatoes, a few cloves smashed and chopped garlic, a packet of  Kaldereta mix that I had sitting in the cupboard, and a sprinkle of sugar to offset a bitter taste that I think came from the worschester)...the upside was that the meat was really tender after crock cooking it for almost 8 hours on low, making the mechado pretty tasty for using salvaged ingredients.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This was good. I followed the recipe except I used low sodium soy sauce and added 3 bell peppers.  Honestly, I could have put in more peppers and I would have been a happy girl.  I will follow other reviewers advice and put the peppers in when there is about 2 hours left to have them be a little less soft.  This dish made a lot of "sauce".  With about 15 minutes remaining, I scooped up 1/3 cup of sauce and mixed a heaping tablespoon of cornstarch.  Wisked it smooth and returned it to the crockpot that I had increased to high.  This thickened it nicely.  We served the meal over egg noodles.  Thanks for sharing.

text:
Cooked this on low for 7 hours, meat was wonderfully tender and delicious. Followed full recipe, only substituting the hot water and boullion with 1/4 cup beef broth. Like other reviewers noted, this is not traditional Chinese Pepper Steak. In fact, the stewed tomatoes gave it a bit if an Italian flare. Also, cooking the peppers for the entire cook time does turn them to mush (but I like them that way).

text:
This is great as written, but I did make some modifications the second time. I used stew meat because that was what I had on hand, and a 12 oz bag of frozen Kroger brand 3 Pepper and Onion Blend, to eliminate the chopping because I was pressed for time. I also increased the water to 1/2 cup, used 2 bouillion cubes instead of one, and 2 Tbsp of cornstarch all because I wanted it to make more gravy than the last time. Very good either way! My family enjoyed this both times, both as written and with the modifications.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
We love this recipe.  The following are the changes I've made due to my family's preferences and time. I don't brown the meat, just slice it up and throw it in the crock pot so I eliminate the oil.I slice a whole onion instead of chopping.  I double the sauce and use low sodium soy sauce or braggs. I also double the tomatoes- 2 cans. I don't add any additional salt.  I use 3-4 cloves of fresh garlic minced and double the peppers or put in 5 or 6. (We love peppers.  I usually take just a little meat and fill my plate with peppers.) I add the peppers in the last hour of cooking.  I've tried it over rice and egg noodles and our favorite is egg noodles. This also freezes pretty well.  I send meals to my daughter in college and she loves this.

country:

text:
I used top round steak because it's what I had.  I seasoned it with salt, pepper, garlic powder and a little ground ginger before browning.  I added minced garlic to the crockpot.  Didn't have beef bouillon so I used Gravy Master instead. Substituted red and orange peppers (personal preference) and brown sugar for the white.  I also omitted the extra salt and used low sodium soy sauce.  Added the peppers in the last hour as suggested.  They would have turned to mush otherwise.  Cooks thoroughly on low in 6-7 hours. Meat was fork tender.  Served over brown rice.  Everyone liked it!  Leftovers make a yummy pita sandwich too.

userID:

Display Name:
Aosborn

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5677176.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This turned out really good.  Very easy to make as well. I sliced up a couple large top sirloin steaks.  I browned them in the oil with about a tbsp of minced garlic, fresh minced ginger and a pinch of red pepper flakes.  I added the browned meat, half a yellow onion cut into strips to the crock pot with the stewed tomatoes and a double batch of the sauce (water, bullion, soy sauce, cornstarch and sugar).  I did omit the salt after reading previous reviews.  After two hours on high I added one sliced up red and one green bell pepper.  Cooked for two more hours on high.  Served it over white rice.  It was good.  The only thing was that it was a little salty.  I probably should have used low sodium soy sauce.  My husband really liked it and said how tender the meat was.  We ate it two nights in a row.  I will make it again.

text:
This was an awesome meal, I altered it a bit and added an extra tablespoon and a half of cornstarch added to 1/3 cup of water.  It's also important to make sure that your water is boiling when adding the bouillon cube, otherwise it wont dissolve very well. The sauce turned out very good and thick with the extra cornstarch.  The meat was tender and served over rice, this is definitely a money maker.

text:
This is my go-to slow cooker recipe. It's always delicious, and every time I make it for company, I'm asked for the recipe. I omit the bouillon because when I'm browning the meat it produces plenty of flavorful liquid, which I just pour into the crock pot, and the teaspoon of salt provides enough saltiness. Sometimes I add a chopped red pepper for a little variety and extra veggies. It's great over brown rice. A real keeper.

I am not a beef eater typically & I love this dish. This is great over egg noodles.

Perfect for new, novice cooks. If I can do this, anyone can. I followed the recipe and looked at some of people's notes. I fell adventurous and added some Goya Sazon, a sprinkle of Adobo and just a pinch of italian seasoning. Served with green beans and Uncle Ben's wild rice, cooked with 1/2 chicken broth instead of water. I ended up getting a standing ovation from my wife and daughter. Delicious.
Review:
Rating:
4

text:
The meat was so tender after cooking it all day that it literally just fell apart. It was delicious. I put the peppers in about 2 hours before serving, so they were soft but not mushy. The only reason it didn't get 5 stars was the sauce had a little too much tomato taste with it. But I would make it again, my husband and I loved it, and ate it over the next few days with pasta, rice, and on bread.

I think next time I will put the stewed tomatoes in a food processor to get the chunks out. A lot of non tomato eaters in this house and it would be easier to disguise them.

I followed this recipe exactly, and it was delish! On my way home from work, I bought a quart of white rice from the chinese take out restaurant to put the peppered steak over.  My husband usually mocks me when I make a slow cooker dish because they usually have no flavor.  But he said I redeemed myself with this dish. I prepared and put everything in the crock the night before. In the morning I just threw it in the crockpot and let it cook on low the whole day until I got home from work. This one is keeper!

text:
This was very good and easy!  I did not need to use the oil to brown the meat, which I browned very lightly.  This dish was actually ready in 4 hours on the slow setting.  I mixed the meat with lots of fresh garlic and some kosher salt before browning.  I used a variety of peppers, including some hot banana peppers, added them later, and actually just kept them on top of the meat until right before serving.  I also used Italian stewed tomatoes and served over egg noodles.  Great flavor.  My family says it's a keeper; success!

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
Changes I made: I subbed cornstarch with flour, minced garlic for garlic powder, and subbed mild rotel for canned tomatoes. Bought the stir-fry steak at the store and sliced the meat up a bit more. Boyfriend LOVED this dish. Coworkers asked for the recipe! Will DEFINITELY make this again!
[Update - I didn't brown the meat in a skillet but instead added the raw meat, with olive oil, and some onion to the crock pot and cooked on High for about 2.5 hours. Then added the rest of the ingredients (minus the peppers -- added those an hour before serving). I cooked on high for about 4.5 hours total. Used  1/2 cup of 99% fat free beef broth (instead of water and bouillon) and served over egg noodles (which have less carbs than white rice or brown rice). We LOVE this recipe!!]

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/101734.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
one of the best slow cooker recipes i have made. followed the reviewers advice of adding peppers and onions toward the end so they stay more firm. i also added some fresh garlic. i would have added some fresh ginger but didnt have any on hand. a great way to use up some of the vension in my freezer. Update: I used to make this quite a bit and forgot about it. So glad I made this again. This last time I didn't have diced tomatoes. I used an 8 oz can of tomato sauce and left out the cornstarch. It thickened nicely on it own. I added peppers, thinly sliced carrots and sugar snap peas during the last 20 mins while I made jasmine rice. Try adding ginger, sriracha, garlic, oyster sauce, whatever you like... Its a terrific base recipe that you can play around with to make your own. Its even good sprinkled with toasted sesame seeds. Yum!!!

I will continue to make this but from now on I will leave the soy sauce out it was better without it anyway! Thanks for posting it really is a good recipe!

text:
This is so delicious and well worth trying. I bought a London Broil (on sale at my grocery store) and cut it into large chunks. Then I sauteed it as directed. Like others suggested I added my sliced peppers to the crock pot an hour before serving and the peppers were tender but not mushy. I used both red and green peppers to make it colorful. The meat was so tender and flavorful. It went great over rice and my hubby cannot stop talking about how great it was. We had left overs for dinner the next night. Definitely a keeper. Thanks for a terrific recipe.

text:
I didn't have any peppers, but needed to use up some sirloin steak.  I sauted the beef with the onions and 1 tbsp. of garlic.  I also added 1 tsp. thyme, 1 tbsp. worchestershire two shakes of pepper flakes and two tsps. of brown sugar instead of the white to the liquid.  One hour before it was ready, I added 1 1/2 c. quartered fresh mushrooms and served over rice with mixed veggies and my 11 yr. old twins had three helpings....no small feat in my household.

text:
I had to make this on the stove due to time constrictions, so I made a couple small changes. I added 1 can of beef consomme (so that it wouldn't dry out during cooking) and about a cup of thinly sliced carrots, then let it simmer on the stove at low heat for about 1-1/2 hours. Served it over steamed rice and oh my gosh was this so good! The flavors of the beef and peppers blended so well and the overall flavor was rich and delicious! A definite keeper! Thanks for the recipe.

text:
Made some modifications and found this to be excellent.  First off, I eliminated the tomatoes; I'm just not wild about combining tomatoes w/soy sauce.  Added 1 T. vinegar and some a few good dashes of red pepper flakes.  I think this gives it a bit more authentic Asian flavor than you would get with the recipe as written - think this would be on the bland side with out the kick of the vinegar/pepper flakes, as others have noted.  I also went w/one red pepper and one green to give it more visual appeal.  Oh, and threw in a can of sliced water chestnuts for crunch.  My husband loved it - leftovers were equally good.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
OK - just made this for the first time and my husband said he thinks this is the best crockpot recipe I have ever made.  I might have to agree.  This was TASTY!!

I browned the meat in a skillet, then I also browned the onion in the skillet.  Put meat then onion in the crockpot.  Dissolved the bouillon in the water, then added the cornstarch, soy sauce, sugar and salt to that liquid mixture.  I poured all of that on top of the meat/onion combo along with the tomatoes and just stirred it up.  It cooked on low in the crockpot for 6.5 hours then I added the peppers (used about 6 peppers instead of just two) and it was all done in another 1.5 hours.  This was simply delicious!  Will definitely make this one again!  Thank You.

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5832066.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Tried this recipe "as is" the first time around and it was very good (definitely add the peppers during the last 1-2 hours of cooking to avoid the mush), but I think I was looking for richer flavor.  Achieved this the second time around by adding a gravy packet (as a previous reviewer suggested) and a can of V8 juice.  I had to use a bit more cornstarch to thicken because of the added liquid.  Also, I cook for six family members, and I found that I needed to double this recipe, as two of the six of us have man-sized appetites.  Served over hot egg noodles, instead of rice. There were no leftovers...  Delish!!! Perfect cool-weather meal!

text:
A save-the-day recipe.  My son has a 2 hr. football practice followed by a 1 hour karate practice, so the slow cooker has become a must in our home!  However, I managed to trip a fuse in the kitchen (construction) and we lost power. When I reset the breaker, I forgot to check the slow cooker before we left for practice. Alas, we arrived home for dinner (starving) and it was not cooked. So I whipped out the pressure cooker dumped the contents of the slow cooker in, and had this meal done in 12 minutes!  So, my 3 hungry guys think I'm a hero!  Great flavor and easy to prep and an inspiration for me to use my pressure cooker more often :)

text:
I made this for friends who came to dinner, and everyone loved it! Make sure you have lots of fluffy rice to go with it. My husband and I ate it for leftovers the next evening, and I took the rest to work for lunch after that. All in all, an excellent slow cooker recipe that leaves the meat very tender and flavorful. However, I am giving four stars because I agree with others who said the vegetables are a bit squishy when it's time to serve. Next time I will start checking for doneness a lot sooner ... maybe an hour or two sooner!

text:
This recipe was absolutely awesome.  I ate nearly the entire thing by myself.  I hate when I read about changes to a recipe, but I had to out of necesiity because I lacked certain ingredients.

First, I only had filet minon so I used that rather than sirloin.  Also, I had no beef bouillon but my dish was plenty beef tasting so I'm not sure what that adds to the recipe.  Also, I like my sauce a little thicker so I added 2 to 3 tablespoons of cornstarch extras during the cooking process.

FYI, this dish heats up REALLY well the next day and is great over a couple of slices of toast.  Thanks again for the recipe!

text:
I made this recipe for dinner tonight and my husband and I both liked it. I served it with mashed potatoes, and the broth was a good topping. I used cubed steaks, and I didn't cut them up. I also added a small can of button mushrooms! This was so easy to prepare. I dredged the cubed steaks in seasoned flour with salt and pepper before browning and threw everything else together while the steak was browning! Everything was together and ready for cooking within 15 minutes and I was out the door for work!

Absolutely delicious. I doubled sauce ingredients and used beef stock instead of boullion cubes. As for the green peppers, I cut them into quarters, added them with meat and removed them 1 hour before serving.  I then added 1/4 yellow pepper, 1/4 red pepper, 1/4 orange pepper, 1/4 the green peppers and 3 cups sliced mushrooms 3/4 hour before serving.  I also used low sodium soy sauce. Results were supurb. Can't wait to make it again.

I had kids in and out of the house all day and each one asked, "What is that delicious smell?"  The meat becomes very tender, the liquids make a nice gravy and the flavor is wonderful.  Thank you Marge!

text:
Made this today and followed the recipe, except I threw in a little more diced oni, and, like others, added the pepper for the last 1.5 hours. Served over rice - easy and delicious! Next time I will add a little more garlic powder ( hubby is not a garlic fan and I didn't want to overdo it)! Will be making again! Make sure you brown the beef first -- it really adds flavor!

text:
Very tender and good pepper steak flavor!
Update:  I used to serve over rice, but I started adding the flavor packet from a beef or oriental top ramen packet and crushing up the noodles over the top of the crockpot towards the end.  Really good!  I also make this when peppers are on sale and use 1 green, 1 red, and 1 yellow or orange.
